2.42.text:
Hello and welcome to this pre-recorded event
for AS Product Design: Graphic Products

12.46.text:
To help you get the most out of this feedback,
you may want to have these following documents

19.70.text:
handy as we will refer to them during the
session.

28.18.text:
We will look at the three aspects of the AS
coursework during this presentation and highlight

33.99.text:
successful and less successful approaches
to the presentation of this work.

41.25.text:
Just to remind you of the requirements in
the 6GR01 course.

50.90.text:
Students must produce a Portfolio of Creative
Skills which is divided into three discernible

56.67.text:
sections:
Product Investigation, Product Design and

69.21.text:
In the Product Investigation section, students
must select a product that contains at least

74.57.text:
two materials and is manufactured using more
than one process.

79.02.text:
They are required to investigate the selected
product under the headings:

84.23.text:
Performance analysis, Materials and Components,
Manufacture, and Quality.

90.84.text:
Students, under teacher guidance, have complete
choice in selecting appropriate products for

96.43.text:
investigation.
The work can be presented in either A3 or

103.42.text:
In Performance Analysis, students are required
to justify how the specification has been

108.26.text:
met for the product under investigation using
the following headings:

113.20.text:
Form - why is the product is shaped or styled
as it is?Function - what is the purpose of

120.99.text:
the product?
User requirements - what qualities make the

126.44.text:
product attractive to potential users?
Performance requirements - what are the technical

133.51.text:
considerations that must be achieved within
the product?

138.44.text:
Material and component requirements - what
are the requirements of the material properties

143.02.text:
in the product performance
Scale of production and cost - how does the

149.01.text:
design allow for scale of production and what
are the considerations in determining cost?

155.48.text:
When analysing a product under these headings,
students should justify statements to say

160.48.text:
why they are important to the product. They
should also say how these needs have been

167.64.text:
Students can investigate any product of their
choosing as long as it consists of a minimum

171.66.text:
of two materials and has been made using more
than a single process.

176.30.text:
As well as justifying the specification for
the selected product, students must identify

181.20.text:
a similar product and compare and contrast
the two using the specification headings described

188.83.text:
In order to compare and contrast effectively,
students must identify differences in the

193.41.text:
two products in order to discuss relative
design features and determine which meets

200.23.text:
It is therefore important that the similar
product is not too similar.

210.69.text:
Where products are too similar in Form, Function,
User requirements, Performance requirements,

216.33.text:
Materials etc, there are fewer opportunities
to identify differences and compare and contrast.

222.55.text:
The product pairings shown here are so closely
related that no effective comparisons can

231.50.text:
The products shown on this slide are similar,
in that they fulfil similar needs, but they

239.27.text:
differ in the way these needs are achieved.
Lots of opportunity to compare and contrast

244.39.text: under the specification headings is offered.

249.87.text:
Here, we are treated to a significant amount
of information.

256.93.text:
The work is a detailed investigation into
one product and then a comparison is made

261.78.text: with another using the technical specification.

264.35.text:
Initially, the detailed input is quite good,
although many statements are sadly unjustified.

271.39.text:
Comparisons have been made to a product that
actually has differences to compare with.

275.94.text:
The comments connect to the product but fail
to be justified fully, however, there are

280.82.text: some connections, so 6 marks were awarded.

289.37.text:
Here is an excellent example of two different
products that are too similar to allow for

297.86.text:
You will note a great deal of 'both games
have', 'both games are' type comments.

304.33.text:
This inability to effectively compare or contrast
products prevents candidates from demonstrating

309.59.text:
as much knowledge as would be demonstrated
by those comparing substantially different

314.61.text:
Obviously, games provide a great deal of opportunities
to allow in-depth manufacturing and materials

320.18.text:
property knowledge to be demonstrated, as
there are a number of component parts within

326.90.text:
Unfortunately, the packaging, games boards
and component parts all utilise similar manufacturing

333.24.text:
processes and materials, hence restricting
opportunities for contrast and comparison.

344.63.text:
In the next part of Product Investigation,
'Materials and components', students are required

350.48.text:
to identify the materials and/or components
used in the making of the product under investigation.

356.63.text:
Only the original product and not the similar
one must be considered in this section and

361.15.text:
the sections that follow.
The similar product is only appropriate to

366.85.text:
Because products will vary in the variety
of materials and components used, it would

372.59.text:
be unfair to ask some students to investigate
all the materials used in a complex product,

377.95.text:
such as a computer game controller, whilst
others looked at the materials used in a bean

382.60.text:
container or a perfume bottle, where the minimum
requirements of two materials is met.

388.96.text:
Taking this into consideration, students are
encouraged to identify only two or three materials/components

395.36.text:
used in their selected product and to investigate
these.

398.80.text:
When identifying properties, this task is
mistakenly seen by many students as an opportunity

403.86.text:
to list everything they know about a material
without any selectivity or justification for

411.34.text:
A moderator does not want to know that a material
is a good electrical insulator when it is

416.36.text:
being use for an underwater application, or
that mild steel contains less that 0.3% carbon

422.72.text: without some reason for presenting this information.

426.26.text:
When material properties are given, it should
be justified as to why they are important

430.64.text:
to the design needs of the product, and not
be part of generic information that could

437.54.text:
Having identified two materials and discussed
advantages and disadvantages, students are

442.58.text:
required to suggest one appropriate alternative
for each of those materials.

447.94.text:
Unfortunately, many alternatives given are
almost identical to the original material,

452.72.text:
especially where plastics are concerned, such
as ABS and HIPS, or PVC and Polypropylene.

459.67.text:
Part of the reasoning behind this section
is to encourage students to use their knowledge

464.37.text:
and understanding of a wide range of materials
when applied to products, giving relevancy

469.27.text:
to their Unit 2 studies and hopefully creating
more interest.

473.15.text:
As part of this section, students should consider
the environmental impact of extracting and

478.35.text:
processing the raw materials used in the product
and their disposal.

482.34.text:
Often, responses are limited to recycling
and generic statements regarding air pollution

495.70.text:
The work submitted here is detailed and informative.
The candidate intelligently informs us about

501.57.text:
the reasons for choosing the materials and
makes some sensible suggestions for alternative

507.60.text:
The work has many qualities of a higher level,
including the discussion of detailed sustainability

516.63.text:
The work is discussed in terms of advantages
and disadvantages, but the comments are not

521.75.text:
specifically connected to the product.
However, there are inherent connections in

526.98.text:
the justifications offered in the commentary,
which allows us to then allocate 8 marks from

535.37.text:
The next task in this unit is to investigate
the manufacture of the product by identifying

543.85.text:
and describing two commercial processes used
and suggesting an appropriate alternative

551.04.text:
When identifying processes, students should
use advantages and disadvantages to justify

555.44.text:
their use in meeting the design and manufacturing
needs of the product.

560.42.text:
Generic statements that could apply to many
other products should be avoided.

565.65.text:
What on the surface of it looks like a thoroughly
produced table on this slide, has significant

570.04.text: weaknesses when looked at in detail.

572.61.text:
Upon closer inspection, it can be seen that
the candidate makes little sense at times,

578.02.text:
but also fails entirely to link the reasons
for use of the manufacture process to the

582.18.text:
product being made.
It could easily be generic information from

587.11.text:
It is often difficult for students to suggest
an appropriate alternative manufacturing process;

592.54.text:
especially where plastic moulding is concerned
which can result in inappropriate processes

599.31.text:
Where there is no real alternative to a process
such as injection moulding, it is acceptable

604.21.text:
for students to suggest a process that would
be appropriate if a different material were

609.24.text: used, as long as they name the material.

612.07.text:
It should be borne in mind that any processes
identified or suggested should be those used

621.29.text:
Students should describe the environmental
impact of using the manufacturing processes

625.01.text:
identified, which will be different to the
effects described in the previous section

633.90.text:
The manufacturing methods are correctly listed
on this slide, although the printing process

641.52.text:
selected could be argued as more likely to
be flexography.

645.38.text:
The processes are not particularly well connected
to the product in their justifications.

651.00.text:
Advantages and disadvantages have been clearly
applied but lack detailed connection to the

656.64.text:
Sustainability issues are raised in a superficial
way; the comments are generic and lack focus.

665.90.text:
It is unlikely that this submission will exceed
any more credit than 7 out of 9 marks.

672.55.text:
It achieves 7-as the mid assessment criteria
has been exceeded.

679.93.text:
The final section in Product Investigation
focuses on 'Quality'.

688.14.text:
To meet assessment requirements, students
must describe a range of quality checks carried

692.22.text:
out during the manufacture of the product,
specifying what the checks would be, how they

696.96.text: would be carried out, and utilising what equipment.

700.12.text:
A quality assurance system should be designed
for the product and this could take the form

705.01.text:
of a flow chart; for example, using headings
such as Preparation, Processing, Assembly,

713.90.text:
Commonly, responses are submitted that describe
what quality control and quality assurance

720.44.text:
are, but what is required is a range of realistic
quality checks as described previously and

726.89.text:
a quality assurance system focused on the
product in hand.

731.38.text:
As part of this section, students should identify
two or three relevant standards and explain

736.91.text:
how they would influence the maintenance of
quality in the manufacture of the product.

740.76.text: It is not enough to simply identify standards.

744.79.text:
Students must say how those standards relate
specifically to the product and its manufacture.

749.96.text:
Here, a sound submission of Quality Assurance
(QA) is offered;

755.33.text:
but not supported by the required Quality
Control (QC) information.

760.64.text:
It relies too heavily on broad statements
identifying check points and does not explain

773.28.text:
The work is not as clearly laid out as it
first appears to be.

777.28.text:
We have a QA system outlined and Quality Standards
are explained clearly.

781.98.text:
The explanation of specific QC points, again,
is not always evident, although some of the

787.11.text:
QA systems have QC exemplified within them.
Hence, we need to adjust within the top range

795.91.text:
Comments are a bit light on how to check,
but they are evident.

800.05.text:
A mark of 4 is the least one would expect
here.

809.12.text:
In the Product Design section, students are
required to submit at least one design task

814.28.text:
appropriate to AS levels of response that
demonstrates their design competencies.

819.65.text:
They are encouraged to be as creative as possible
and to support this, there is no requirement

824.98.text:
for the designed product to be manufactured,
which means no constraints are placed on designs

830.50.text:
through the limitation of resources found
in centres.

834.33.text:
Students have the option in Product Manufacture
of making what they design or making something

840.28.text:
In the course of designing, students are expected
to produce a range of initial design ideas

845.37.text:
accompanied by technical annotation, a review
of design ideas based on product specification

851.89.text:
requirements, and develop designs into a final
proposal that includes enough detail which

856.80.text:
would allow a skilled third party to manufacture
the intended product.

861.55.text:
Students, under teacher guidance, have complete
choice in selecting appropriate design briefs.

868.58.text:
More than a single design brief may be undertaken,
depending on the skills a teacher wants to

873.01.text:
develop in their students. Most however pursue
a single design task.

879.69.text: Work should be presented in A3 format.

881.01.text:
The starting point for the Product Design
exercise is to present some measurable design

887.64.text:
criteria. This is used as a guide and reference
point as designing progresses, and later in

898.37.text:
Here, we see a selection of starting points.
All of them are appropriate as no limits are

906.57.text: placed on what should be designed.

909.44.text:
We have garden furniture, cosmetic packaging
and a games console controller.

914.99.text:
The latter two are more readily appropriate
to Graphic Products, though this is not a

921.72.text:
It could be argued that furniture design does
not lend itself to supporting the additional

926.30.text:
parts of the specification as well as the
other two briefs.

930.41.text:
What all three have in common, however, is
a design brief given or developed by the student,

935.79.text:
and a simple design specification, which can
be used as an evaluative tool during the process.

943.71.text:
The starting point for our example design
product is a redesign on an existing brand

955.32.text:
The brief explains the needs of the assignment
and then a specification is offered for later

968.12.text:
On this slide, we a selection of design images
for perfume bottles.

972.72.text:
The designer has utilised a variety of inputs
for the generation of ideas and has attempted

979.05.text:
to illuminate how a number of sub-systems
could be made to work effectively, and how

983.50.text: they would affect the design outcome.

986.58.text:
Good use of technical terminology has been
used with some use of decision making and

994.36.text:
The work is then formally evaluated against
the specification for each design of the bottles.

1000.17.text:
The work does not have great depth of change
or design exploration.

1005.15.text:
Technical aspects are covered but bottles
are obviously quite similar in manufacture

1009.04.text: process so some restrictions would be expected.

1012.71.text:
The work is however supported by the design
for the box that the bottle will be contained

1018.48.text:
within later.
Hence, it is always useful to view this section

1022.35.text:
holistically to ensure that a full picture
is gained before the assessment is made.

1030.06.text:
The bottle is developed along the lines of
the individual sub-systems in the lolly idea

1038.09.text: after the butterfly idea is discarded.

1041.31.text:
Modelling is utilised and used to change ideas
and move the whole concept forward.

1047.32.text: Review is included and decisions are recorded.

1051.28.text:
This is not the only development work to be
credited. We also have to consider the development

1055.89.text: of the box and its external graphics too.

1065.47.text:
We have now returned to designing evidence.
Here, the box graphics are considered and

1070.94.text: a variety of boxes are trialled.

1073.41.text:
These are likely to be existing nets from
a commercial source, but this is what might

1078.40.text: be expected from a commercial designer.

1081.29.text:
The nets are trialled and then changes are
incorporated to meet the requirements of the

1085.96.text:
designed bottle.
Obviously, the bottle ideas will need to be

1089.64.text: finalised before the box can be designed.

1092.89.text:
There is excellent use of modelling here.
It is not just a presentation tool or offered

1097.47.text:
as a 'fait accompli', but has been used as
a tool to check and evaluate the changes being

1106.74.text:
Here, the net has been changed and the final
shape of the box decided upon.

1115.54.text:
The designer then develops the final style
or presentation graphic to be applied to the

1121.97.text:
This is a good opportunity to use CAD as part
of the design process.

1126.60.text:
Again, this should be used as a tool to trial
changes, not just as a presentation device.

1135.32.text:
Here, we see a final design proposal presented
with the detail required for manufacture.

1143.54.text:
This detail can be for commercial or modelling
purposes.

1147.24.text:
What is required is the comprehensive nature
of the detail to enable some form of manufacture

1154.67.text:
The design work for the bottle and box seen
holistically is varied, workable and has a

1161.44.text:
The development is particularly good with
extensive use of modelling and CAD to develop

1166.89.text:
and resolve design changes.
This is excellent work for this level, and

1172.13.text:
there should be no doubt about a high assessment
in this section.

1175.65.text:
The communication of the work is crisp and
well presented in places, the more formal

1182.49.text:
The annotation is detailed and well communicated
but the information offered in the working

1187.06.text:
drawings leaves little to the imagination
in terms of sizes and the actual net to be

1194.24.text:
The marks in this section should be in the
top assessment criterion, but towards the

1202.56.text:
It goes without saying that the design work
here is detailed and varied.

1211.11.text:
The candidate is making great efforts to explore
all sorts of opportunities in the design of

1220.97.text:
Here, the work is too fixed in single idea
outcomes, with very few changes or detail

1231.06.text:
It should also be noted that the CAD work
is not really reviewed or used to trial new

1237.16.text:
ideas or changes, and the specification is
not connected to the ideas being considered.

1243.84.text:
Modelling is also used but as a presentational
tool, to trial the final design where no further

1249.59.text:
changes were then offered after the modelling
had taken place.

1258.76.text:
In Product Manufacture students are required
to plan, make and test one or more products

1264.92.text:
that match the manufacturing criteria of the
task.

1267.85.text:
It is key for this part of the portfolio that
a range of advanced processes and manufacturing

1273.28.text:
skills are evidenced.
This is usually evidenced through a range

1277.06.text:
of products being made, although it may be
possible to demonstrate a range of processes

1281.68.text:
through one product if it is demanding enough
and requires a range of processes.

1287.05.text:
In this section of the portfolio, it is strongly
recommended that teachers set the manufacturing

1291.82.text:
tasks in order to ensure that students improve
competencies and learn new skills in preparation

1299.23.text:
It is a rule that where CAM is used, it must
not exceed 50% of product manufacture.

1306.72.text:
Where more than one product is made, planning
and testing should only be evidenced once.

1311.54.text:
It is a requirement that clear photographic
evidence is submitted that shows the quality

1317.57.text:
and complexity of challenge relating to all
manufacturing tasks.

1321.37.text:
This can be added in the portfolio as a manufacturing
diary and preferably should be for all products

1329.90.text:
Work in this section should be presented in
A3 format.

1335.82.text:
This Gantt chart has no specific timings.
This not an issue if the chart is to identify

1345.72.text:
key deadlines, but the work has focused on
the identification of the key folder deadlines

1350.97.text:
and not the manufacturing aspects.
This is largely of no merit.

1357.30.text:
In this case, this Gantt chart shows information
relating to the actual manufacture of the

1367.37.text:
product in this case, which helps in providing
evidence of key deadlines but it does not

1372.53.text:
contain enough information to form a detailed
production plan.

1376.25.text:
It should also be noted that the manufacturing
processes rely a lot on the single manufacturing

1382.16.text:
process that being CAM outputs and is likely
not to represent a wide enough range of processes

1388.92.text:
for marks at the highest level in this section
alone.

1394.94.text:
Here, we see an example of a high performing
candidate in this section.

1402.40.text: The product is a model of an existing building.

1406.24.text:
The candidate shows what is intended, provides
a simple manufacturing specification for use

1411.19.text:
in the evaluation section later, and justifies
the manufacturing processes and the materials

1421.18.text:
The candidate has offered a breakdown of the
major deadlines and their approximate timings.

1428.83.text:
This could be argued as being even a little
too detailed as it is only expected that the

1434.17.text:
main component parts be detailed.
This is top submission in this part of the

1440.85.text:
The 
manufacture of the architectural model has
been well documented as can be seen from the

1454.60.text:
The final product is adequately made but relies
quite heavily on laser cutting.

1459.65.text:
It is fortunate that the candidate also submitted
the following model, seen on the next slide.

1468.46.text:
Here, we can see the second product made by
the candidate - a point of sale display for

1476.08.text:
a perfume bottle.
New packaging was also designed for the existing

1481.63.text:
Clearly with colour sublimation, sheet metal
work and graphic image manipulation, this

1487.50.text:
candidate has enhanced the range of skills
from the previous model that relied a little

1493.74.text:
The work is deemed to be a top quality response
in this section if not at the very top end.

1501.89.text:
The final part of product manufacture is'Testing'
and this should be done using measurable performance

1510.60.text:
related criteria that should have been set
at the beginning of this section.

1515.19.text:
Wherever possible, field-trials should be
used to test a product's fitness for purpose

1519.65.text: and superficial testing should be avoided.

1522.26.text:
Tests to see whether a product is aesthetically
pleasing or includes particular named materials

1528.59.text:
or techniques are not valid. Tests should
be technical and rigorous.

1535.15.text:
Tests should also be objective and described
in terms of what was being tested, how the

1539.97.text:
test was carried out, and what the results
were.

1543.59.text:
Where third party testing is used, superficial,
congratulatory statements should be avoided.

1548.92.text:
The same performance criteria used by the
student-maker should be used in third party

1554.49.text:
testing to ensure objectivity.
Testing of the second product is not required.

1561.84.text:
Here, testing is offered and explained but
not justified.

1566.58.text:
The testing is realistic and objectively considered.
There is third party evaluation and the results

1573.32.text:
of the tests appear to have been taken into
account.

1575.85.text:
It is a good performance but only scores 5
out of 6 due to the lack of justification
